turn.0: Hi, I'm your automated assistant. I can answer your questions about Galaxy.
turn.1: What is the Local Group of galaxies?
turn.2: The Local Group itself is a part of a cloud-like structure within the Virgo Supercluster, a large, extended structure of groups and clusters of galaxies centered on the Virgo Cluster.
turn.3: Are there any other interesting aspects about this article?
turn.4: And the Virgo Supercluster itself is a part of the Pisces-Cetus Supercluster Complex, a giant galaxy filament.
turn.5: What do you find most interesting about the local group of galaxies?
turn.6: The peak radiation of most stars lies in the visible spectrum, so the observation of the stars that form galaxies has been a major component of optical astronomy.
turn.7: Is there anything else that is interesting about this article?
turn.8: It is also a favorable portion of the spectrum for observing ionized H II regions, and for examining the distribution of dusty arms.
turn.9: What are some of the arms of the local group?
turn.10: The dust present in the interstellar medium is opaque to visual light.
turn.11: What else is the interstellar medium?
turn.12: It is more transparent to far-infrared, which can be used to observe the interior regions of giant molecular clouds and galactic cores in great detail.
